What are my patient rights?
As a patient, you have rights regardless of your sex, economic status, educational background, race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, or the source of payment for care. These rights include:   1. Considerate and respectful care. 2. Knowing the name of the physician who has primary responsibility for coordinating care and the names and professional relationships of other physicians and non-physicians who will see you. 3. Getting information about your illness, treatment, and prospects for recovery in understandable terms. 4. Getting as much information about any proposed treatment or procedure as you may need to give informed consent or to refuse the course of treatment. 5. Participating actively in decisions regarding your medical care, including the right to refuse treatment. 6. Full consideration of privacy concerning your medical care program. 7. Confidential treatment of all communications and records pertaining to your care and stay in the hospital. 8. Reasonable responses to any reasonable requests made for service. 9. Leaving the hospital even against the advice of physicians (except for patients involuntarily detained by order of the court). 10. Reasonable continuity of care and knowing in advance the time and location of appointments as well as the identity of persons providing the care. 11. Being informed of continuing healthcare requirements following discharge from the hospital. 12. Examining and receiving an explanation of the bill regardless of source of payment. 13. Knowing which hospital rules and policies apply to your conduct while a patient. 14. Having all of your rights apply to the person who may have legal responsibility to make decisions regarding medical care on your behalf. 15. Designating visitors of your choosing, if you have decision making capacity, whether or not the visitor is related by blood or marriage. 16. Having your wishes considered for purposes of determining who may visit if you lack decision making capacity. 17. Being free from seclusion and restraints used in behavior management unless clinically necessary.
CONTEXT 2: This chunk does not seem relevant to the question
How much will I have to pay?
You have the right to receive a Good Faith Estimate for the total expected cost of any health care items or services upon request or when scheduling such items or services. This includes related costs like medical tests, prescription drugs, equipment, and hospital fees. If you schedule a health care item or service at least 3 business days in advance, your health care provider or facility should give you a Good Faith Estimate in writing within 1 business day after scheduling. If you schedule a health care item or service at least 10 business days in advance, they should give you a Good Faith Estimate in writing within 3 business days after scheduling. If you receive a bill that is at least $400 more for any provider or facility than your Good Faith Estimate from that provider or facility, you can dispute the bill.
CONTEXT 3: This chunk does not seem relevant to the question
How much does a visit to the ER cost? 
Under the law, health care providers need to give patients who don’t have certain types of health care coverage or who are not using certain types of health care coverage an estimate of their bill for health care items and services before those items or services are provided. You have the right to receive a Good Faith Estimate for the total expected cost of any health care items or services upon request or when scheduling such items or services. This includes related costs like medical tests, prescription drugs, equipment, and hospital fees. If you receive a bill that is at least $400 more for any provider or facility than your Good Faith Estimate from that provider or facility, you can dispute the bill. For uninsured individuals, hospitals must provide the patient with a written estimate of the amount the hospital will require for the expected services at the time of service.</TASK>

Yes, there is a policy for discharge planning. This policy establishes the process for patient discharge, including comprehensive discharge instructions, post-discharge care coordination, and follow-up appointments to support continuity of care. The policy also mandates medication reconciliation to ensure patient safety and optimal treatment outcomes. The policy applies to all patients receiving care within the hospital, including inpatient and outpatient settings, and healthcare professionals involved in the discharge planning process. The discharge planning process begins promptly upon admission to identify patients' needs for post-discharge care and support. The attending physician, in collaboration with the interdisciplinary care team, assesses the patient's medical condition, social support, and functional abilities to determine appropriate post-discharge care arrangements. The discharge planning team collaborates with patients, their families, and relevant healthcare providers to facilitate seamless transitions of care. The team also assesses and coordinates any necessary post-discharge services, including home healthcare, rehabilitation, medical equipment, physical therapy, or other support services. The attending physician, in consultation with the interdisciplinary care team, determines the appropriate timing and nature of follow-up appointments for each patient. Medication reconciliation is conducted at admission, during the hospital stay, and at the time of discharge. Compliance with this policy is monitored through regular audits and review of discharge planning documentation. All healthcare professionals involved in the discharge planning process receive adequate education and training on the principles and procedures outlined in this policy. This Discharge Planning Policy is approved by the hospital leadership and is reviewed periodically to ensure its continued relevance, effectiveness, and compliance with regulatory standards.
